classifications.note: E=mc² where E is rest energy, m is rest mass, c is light speed. Rest energy: E₀=mc². Total energy: E=γmc². Kinetic energy: K=(γ-1)mc². Mass-energy equivalence means mass can be converted to energy and vice versa.

principles.principle: Foundation and Meaning of Mass-Energy Equivalence
principles.statement: E=mc² represents one of the most profound insights in physics, with multiple derivations and deep implications: Einstein's Original Derivation (1905): Consider object emitting two equal light pulses in opposite directions; From conservation of momentum, object remains at rest; But energy is lost from system; From relativity, this energy loss corresponds to mass decrease Δm = ΔE/c²; Thus E=mc². Work-Energy Theorem Derivation: Work done on relativistic particle: dE = F·dx = (dp/dt)·dx = v·dp; From p=γmv, integrate to find total energy; Result: E=γmc²; For v=0, E₀=mc² (rest energy). Four-Vector Formalism: Four-momentum P = (E/c, pₓ, p_y, p_z); Lorentz invariant: P·P = m²c²; Thus E² - p²c² = m²c⁴; For p=0, E=mc². Physical Interpretation: Mass and energy are equivalent; Mass is concentrated form of energy; Energy has gravitational mass; Conversion possible in certain processes. Rest Energy Concept: E₀=mc² is energy of object at rest; Even stationary objects contain enormous energy; 1 kg matter has energy 9×10¹⁶ J (equivalent to 21 megatons TNT). Mass-Energy Conservation: In isolated systems, total mass-energy conserved; Mass can convert to other forms of energy; Total relativistic energy always conserved. Historical Significance: Resolved mystery of radioactive energy source; Explained stellar energy production; Revolutionized understanding of energy and matter. Why c² Appears: c² is conversion factor between mass and energy units; In SI: 1 kg = 9×10¹⁶ J; Large factor explains why nuclear energy is so potent; In natural units (c=1), E=m directly. Experimental Verification: Nuclear reactions show mass defect; Particle-antiparticle annihilation; All consistent with E=mc².
principles.application: Derive E=mc² using different methods. Calculate rest energies of particles. Understand physical meaning of equivalence. Apply to energy conversion problems. Appreciate historical development. Verify with experimental data.
principles.example: Electron: m=9.11×10⁻³¹ kg, E₀=8.19×10⁻¹⁴ J=0.511 MeV. Proton: E₀=938 MeV. 1 uranium atom fission: ~200 MeV released from mass conversion.
principles.analogy: Like discovering that money can be in different currencies - mass and energy are different 'currencies' for the same fundamental 'wealth', with c² as the enormous exchange rate; what seemed like separate concepts are actually interchangeable

worked_examples.title: Rest Energy Calculations
worked_examples.problem: Calculate rest energy for: (a) Electron (m=9.11×10⁻³¹ kg), (b) Proton (m=1.67×10⁻²⁷ kg), (c) 1 gram of matter, (d) Compare with everyday energy scales.

step_by_step.explanation: 1 gram energy = 9×10¹³ J; Hiroshima bomb = 6.3×10¹³ J; 1 kg TNT = 4.2×10⁶ J; So 1 gram matter energy ≈ 1.4 Hiroshima bombs
Nuclear reactions tap tiny fractions of this energy (0.1% for fission, 0.7% for fusion). Chemical reactions use even smaller fractions (~10⁻⁹).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Electron: 0.511 MeV, (b) Proton: 938 MeV, (c) 1 gram: 9×10¹³ J ≈ 21 kilotons TNT, (d) Enormous energy content in ordinary matter.

image.caption: Rest energy calculations for various masses

worked_examples.title: Mass-Energy Conversion in Nuclear Reactions
worked_examples.problem: In deuterium-tritium fusion: D + T → ⁴He + n + 17.6 MeV. Calculate: (a) Mass defect, (b) Fraction of mass converted, (c) Compare with chemical reactions.

step_by_step.explanation: D mass = 2.014102 u, T mass = 3.016049 u, total = 5.030151 u; 1 u = 1.66×10⁻²⁷ kg, so total m = 8.35×10⁻²⁷ kg
Typical chemical reaction: ~1 eV per atom, fraction ~10⁻⁹ of rest energy. Nuclear fusion: 10⁶× more energy per mass.
Explains why nuclear energy is millions of times more potent than chemical energy.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Mass defect=3.13×10⁻²⁹ kg, (b) 0.375% of mass converted to energy, (c) Nuclear reactions ~10⁶× more efficient than chemical reactions. Demonstrates power of mass-energy conversion.

classifications.note: Fission: heavy nuclei split, ~0.1% mass conversion, ~200 MeV per fission. Fusion: light nuclei combine, ~0.7% mass conversion, ~17 MeV per fusion (D-T). Binding energy per nucleon peaks at iron-56. Stars fuse hydrogen to helium, converting mass to energy.

principles.statement: Nuclear processes provide the most dramatic demonstrations of E=mc², with enormous energy releases from small mass conversions: Nuclear Fission: Heavy nuclei (uranium, plutonium) split into medium-mass fragments; Total mass of fragments less than original nucleus; Mass defect converted to energy (~200 MeV per ²³⁵U fission); Typical conversion: 0.1% of mass to energy; Chain reactions possible for energy production. Nuclear Fusion: Light nuclei (hydrogen, helium) combine to form heavier elements; Mass of product less than sum of reactants; Mass defect converted to energy; In stars: proton-proton chain converts H to He; 0.7% of mass converted to energy; Potential future energy source. Binding Energy Curve: Plot of binding energy per nucleon vs atomic mass; Minimum for hydrogen, maximum for iron-56; Fission: move toward peak (heavy→medium); Fusion: move toward peak (light→medium); Energy released in both cases. Mass Defect Calculations: For any nuclear reaction: Δm = m_initial - m_final; Energy released: ΔE = Δm c²; Using atomic mass units: 1 u = 931.494 MeV/c²; Precise mass measurements verify predictions. Fission Reactors: ²³⁵U absorbs thermal neutron, splits; Average 2.5 neutrons produced, sustaining chain reaction; Controlled by neutron absorption; 1 kg ²³⁵U → 8.2×10¹³ J (equivalent to 3000 tons coal). Fusion Energy: Deuterium-tritium reaction: D + T → ⁴He + n + 17.6 MeV; Requires high temperature (∼10⁸ K) for Coulomb barrier penetration; In stars: gravity provides confinement; On Earth: magnetic or inertial confinement. Stellar Nucleosynthesis: Main sequence stars: H → He via p-p chain or CNO cycle; 0.7% mass conversion powers stars for billions of years; Later stages: He → C, O, up to Fe; Supernovae create heavier elements. Nuclear Weapons: Uncontrolled chain reactions; Fission bombs: critical mass assembly; Fusion (thermonuclear) bombs: use fission to initiate fusion; Enormous energy from small amounts of matter. Why Nuclear Energy is So Potent: Chemical reactions: electron rearrangement, ~1 eV energy; Nuclear reactions: nuclear rearrangement, ~10⁶ eV energy; Factor of millions in energy density; Direct consequence of E=mc².
principles.application: Calculate energy from mass defects. Analyze fission and fusion reactions. Understand binding energy significance. Apply to reactor design problems. Compare nuclear and chemical energy. Evaluate practical energy sources.
principles.example: Sun: converts 4×10⁹ kg/s mass to energy, powering solar radiation. Nuclear reactor: 1 kg uranium = 3×10⁶ kg coal energy equivalent.
principles.analogy: Like the difference between rearranging furniture in a house (chemical energy - small effect) versus rebuilding the house's foundation (nuclear energy - massive effect); E=mc² explains why nuclear changes release millions of times more energy than chemical changes

worked_examples.title: Uranium Fission Energy Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Calculate energy release from ²³⁵U fission: ²³⁵U + n → ¹⁴¹Ba + ⁹²Kr + 3n. Masses: ²³⁵U=235.043923 u, n=1.008665 u, ¹⁴¹Ba=140.914411 u, ⁹²Kr=91.926156 u.

step_by_step.explanation: This specific channel gives 173 MeV. Average over all possible fission products is ~200 MeV. Mass conversion fraction ~200/235000=0.085%.

worked_examples.final_answer: Energy release = 173.2 MeV for this fission channel. Average ~200 MeV per fission. Demonstrates mass-energy conversion in nuclear fission.

worked_examples.title: Solar Fusion Energy Production
worked_examples.problem: The Sun radiates 3.8×10²⁶ W. Calculate: (a) Mass converted per second, (b) Fraction of solar mass converted in 10 billion years, (c) Total energy released if 10% of hydrogen fused.

step_by_step.explanation: M_sun = 2×10³⁰ kg
t = 10¹⁰ years = 3.16×10¹⁷ s; Total mass converted = 4.22×10⁹ × 3.16×10¹⁷ = 1.33×10²⁷ kg; Fraction = 1.33×10²⁷/2×10³⁰ = 0.00067 = 0.067%
Solar composition: ~75% H, so 10% of H = 0.075 M_sun = 1.5×10²⁹ kg; Energy from fusion: 0.007×1.5×10²⁹×c² = 0.007×1.5×10²⁹×9×10¹⁶ = 9.45×10⁴³ J
t = E/P = 9.45×10⁴³/3.8×10²⁶ = 2.49×10¹⁷ s = 7.9×10⁹ years - reasonable main sequence lifetime

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 4.22×10⁹ kg/s mass conversion, (b) 0.067% of solar mass in 10 billion years, (c) 10% H fusion provides ~8 billion year energy. Shows stellar energy scale.

principles.principle: Modern Applications and Implications of E=mc²
principles.statement: Mass-energy equivalence continues to find new applications and deepen our understanding across multiple fields: Medical Applications: PET Scanning (Positron Emission Tomography): Uses β⁺ emitters (¹¹C, ¹³N, ¹⁵O, ¹⁸F); Positrons annihilate with electrons: e⁺ + e⁻ → 2γ (511 keV each); Detecting γ rays provides 3D metabolic imaging; Direct application of particle-antiparticle annihilation. Radiation Therapy: Proton therapy: uses relativistic protons from cyclotrons; Bragg peak allows precise tumor targeting; Dose calculation requires relativistic energy formulas; Hadron therapy uses heavier ions. Particle Physics Research: Particle Accelerators: Convert kinetic energy to new particles via E=mc²; LHC: proton collisions create Higgs boson, top quarks, etc.; Conservation of mass-energy fundamental to all analyses; Verification of E=mc² to high precision. Cosmology and Astrophysics: Stellar Evolution: main sequence stars fuse H→He (0.7% mass conversion); Supernovae: create heavy elements and disperse them; Cosmic rays: high-energy particles from astrophysical processes; Big Bang: initial energy converted to particles. Nuclear Power Generation: Fission reactors: practical implementation of E=mc²; Currently ~10% world electricity from nuclear power; Fusion research: seeking to replicate stellar energy production; Radioisotope thermoelectric generators for space missions. Materials Analysis and Dating: Radiocarbon dating: ¹⁴C decay used for archaeology; Other isotopic dating methods (K-Ar, U-Pb); Materials analysis using nuclear techniques; Industrial radiography. Technological Spin-offs: Nuclear medicine diagnostics and treatment; Radiation processing of materials; Nuclear batteries for remote applications; Scientific instrumentation development. Future Applications: Advanced nuclear reactors (Generation IV); Potential fusion power plants; Space propulsion concepts; Matter-antimatter propulsion (theoretical); Quantum gravity research. Philosophical Implications: Matter and energy fundamentally unified; Conservation of mass-energy replaces separate conservation; Deep connection between fundamental physics and cosmology; Limits on energy extraction and conversion. Why E=mc² Remains Relevant: Foundation of nuclear physics and particle physics; Essential for understanding stellar processes; Basis of important technologies; Continues to inspire new research; Symbol of deep physical insight.

worked_examples.title: PET Scan Physics Calculation
worked_examples.problem: In PET scanning, ¹⁸F (fluorine-18) decays emitting positrons. Calculate: (a) Energy per annihilation, (b) Photon energy from e⁺e⁻ annihilation, (c) Why two photons are produced.

step_by_step.explanation: e⁺ + e⁻ total mass = 2m_e = 1.022 MeV/c²
E_total = 2m_ec² = 1.022 MeV
Typically two photons produced, each with E_γ = m_ec² = 0.511 MeV
Momentum conservation requires at least two photons in opposite directions; Single photon cannot conserve both energy and momentum for stationary e⁺e⁻ pair.
511 keV photons ideal for medical detection - good tissue penetration but still detectable. Coincidence detection of back-to-back photons allows precise localization.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Total energy=1.022 MeV per annihilation, (b) Each photon=0.511 MeV, (c) Two photons needed for momentum conservation. Basis of PET medical imaging.

image.caption: Physics calculations for PET medical imaging

worked_examples.title: Particle Creation in LHC
worked_examples.problem: LHC protons collide with 6.5 TeV each (total 13 TeV CM energy). Calculate: (a) Maximum particle mass creatable, (b) Compare with known particles, (c) Energy available for Higgs production.

step_by_step.explanation: In CM frame, total energy available for particle creation = 13 TeV; Maximum mass m_max = E_total/c² = 13 TeV/c²
Proton mass = 0.938 GeV/c²; Higgs mass = 125 GeV/c²; Top quark = 173 GeV/c²; So 13 TeV = 13,000 GeV, much larger than known particles
Higgs mass = 125 GeV/c²; Significant energy available for Higgs production; Actual production cross-sections depend on detailed physics
Most energy goes into kinetic energy of produced particles; Only small fraction available for rest mass creation due to momentum conservation; Higgs production rare process.
For two protons colliding head-on, maximum mass creation occurs when products are at rest in CM frame; But this is rare - usually multiple particles produced with kinetic energy.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Maximum creatable mass=13 TeV/c², (b) Much heavier than known particles (proton=0.000938 TeV), (c) Plenty of energy for Higgs (0.125 TeV) and other particle production. Shows LHC energy scale.

common_misconceptions: Thinking E=mc² means mass converts to energy in chemical reactions
Believing nuclear reactions violate conservation laws
Confusing mass-energy equivalence with matter creation
Believing E=mc² is only about nuclear weapons
Confusing rest energy with total energy
summary: Einstein's mass-energy equivalence E=mc² establishes that mass and energy are interchangeable, with mass representing a highly concentrated form of energy. The equation reveals that ordinary matter contains enormous energy, with 1 kilogram equivalent to 9×10¹⁶ joules. This principle explains the energy source in nuclear reactions, where small mass defects (0.1-0.7% of mass) convert to large energy releases, making nuclear energy millions of times more potent than chemical energy. Applications span nuclear power, medical imaging (PET scans), radiation therapy, particle physics research, and understanding stellar processes. E=mc² continues to underpin modern technologies while demonstrating the profound unity of physical concepts and inspiring ongoing research into matter-energy transformations.
